text: Hi, I’m Francis,
the host of this show "Cooking with Dog."
First, grate the daikon radish with a grater.
The skin of the daikon has a pungent taste
and rough texture so remove it beforehand.
Strain the grated daikon to remove the excess liquid.
Next, let’s rinse the oysters.
Dissolve the salt in a bowl of water.
Gently rinse the oysters in the salt water
and carefully remove the sand between the creases.
Remove
and quickly rinse them with a large amount of cold fresh water.
Drain the oysters with a mesh strainer
and pour cold water over them to rinse thoroughly.
Place the oysters onto a paper towel
and remove the excess moisture.
Now, add a small amount of ponzu sauce
and toss to coat.
This will help to keep the oysters from getting mushy.
Place the oysters into a bowl.
Add the grated daikon radish
and sprinkle on the chopped spring onion leaves.
Pour on the ponzu sauce.
Finally, garnish with the ichimi, red chili powder.
If you don’t like the smell of oysters,
rinse them with grated daikon radish to soften the smell.
Ponzu sauce is often sold at Asian markets
but you can also make it at home.
To do that, please watch our Buri Shabu-Shabu video.
Enjoy this simple, delicious Japanese-inspired way
of eating fresh raw oysters.
Good luck in the kitchen.
